resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

worklogs.comment:
nevi-me commented on pull request #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150
 
 
   This PR enables support for temporal casts, mostly taking advantage of the `divide` and `multiply` arithmetic kernels.
   
   TODO:
   - [ ] reduce code repetition
   - [ ] tests
   - [ ] benchmark all temporal kernels
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

nevi-me commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482810551
 
 
   My observations so far:
   
   As temporal arrays are only 32-bit and 64-bit, I've noticed the following that has an effect on performance.
   
   * 64-bit to 64-bit: it's mostly multiplying/dividing by some constant, and `crate::compute::kernels::multiply` is the fastest path (that I know) for mul, but div is a bit slower
   * 64-bit to 32-bit: `crate::compute::kernels::multiply` doesn't yet make sense as it's not SIMD enabled. The fastest option is to divide value-by-value. Even if `divide` could become faster, `numeric_cast` is currently value-by-value to convert from i64 to i32. That's where perf takes a hit
   * 32-bit to 64-bit: `multiply` is fast, but gets slowed down by `numeric_cast`. This option still comes out faster than value-by-value conversion
   * 32-bit to 32-bit: same as 64-64
   
   There's a bit of noise on my machine, so I'm going to try benchmarking from an isolated machine in the coming days.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

nevi-me commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482832267
 
 
   Here's current performance (on a system with little noise)
   
   ```rust
   cast date64 to date32 512
                           time:   [44.923 us 45.084 us 45.251 us]
   Found 6 outliers among 100 measurements (6.00%)
     2 (2.00%) high mild
     4 (4.00%) high severe
   
   cast date32 to date64 512
                           time:   [17.116 us 17.216 us 17.339 us]
                           change: [+3.0655% +5.2595% +7.5913%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                           Performance has regressed.
   Found 18 outliers among 100 measurements (18.00%)
     3 (3.00%) high mild
     15 (15.00%) high severe
   
   cast time32s to time32ms 512
                           time:   [1.7623 us 1.7760 us 1.7942 us]
   Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
     2 (2.00%) high mild
     1 (1.00%) high severe
   ```

paddyhoran commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482855989
 
 
   > but div is a bit slower
   
   Divide is not SIMD enabled yet.  It will probably be my next PR.
   
   > `crate::compute::kernels::multiply` doesn't yet make sense as it's not SIMD enabled. 
   
   `multiply` is SIMD enabled, maybe you are referring to something else?

nevi-me commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482810551
 
 
   My observations so far:
   
   As temporal arrays are only 32-bit and 64-bit, I've noticed the following that has an effect on performance.
   
   * 64-bit to 64-bit: it's mostly multiplying/dividing by some constant, and `crate::compute::kernels::multiply` is the fastest path (that I know) for mul, but div is a bit slower
   * 64-bit to 32-bit: `crate::compute::kernels::divide` doesn't yet make sense as it's not SIMD enabled. The fastest option is to divide value-by-value. Even if `divide` could become faster, `numeric_cast` is currently value-by-value to convert from i64 to i32. That's where perf takes a hit
   * 32-bit to 64-bit: `multiply` is fast, but gets slowed down by `numeric_cast`. This option still comes out faster than value-by-value conversion
   * 32-bit to 32-bit: same as 64-64
   
   There's a bit of noise on my machine, so I'm going to try benchmarking from an isolated machine in the coming days.

nevi-me commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482857079
 
 
   Yes @paddyhoran, I copied from `multiply` but omitted changing to `divide`. While you're on the line, is there a way I could use SIMD on iterating functions like https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/e1780f235febb2bce0da0cb2beb7825268242d74/rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs#L531? it's the main thing slowing down casts

paddyhoran commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-482908472
 
 
   Hey @nevi-me, yea I think you could.  I have not used them much but there are [casting ops](https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/packed_simd/packed_simd/?search=cast) for the SIMD intrinsics.  Probably something we can address separately.

nevi-me commented on issue #4150: ARROW-4806: [Rust] Temporal array casts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4150#issuecomment-483065856
 
 
   Hi @sunchao @andygrove @paddyhoran please review when you get a chance. I don't know how much time I'll have in the next few days, so I'm asking for feedback if you'll have time before I look at it again.
   
   ## Status
   
   * I think I've covered all the temporal cast cases that I wanted to cover
   * I can add a few more tests to increase test coverage, but I'm so far comfortable that I haven't missed anything major
   * @sunchao there might be a few more places where I can replace repetitive code with generics, I'll think about it during the week. I can also use a generic function to create bench arrays, so I'll do that when I add all the other non-temporal casts, perhaps as a separate JIRA
   * I'll add more benchmarks if what we have isn't enough, but I've had enough to determine which directions to take for each of the cast ops. Other than with SIMD, not sure if we can make them any faster
   
   Here's the output of the benchmarks:
   
   ```rust
   cast int32 to int32 512 time:   [496.80 ns 501.28 ns 507.78 ns]
                           change: [-1.3792% +0.3933% +2.2085%] (p = 0.68 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 6 outliers among 100 measurements (6.00%)
     3 (3.00%) high mild
     3 (3.00%) high severe
   
   cast int64 to int32 512 time:   [15.551 us 15.692 us 15.858 us]
                           change: [-0.1984% +0.4716% +1.3027%] (p = 0.23 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 7 outliers among 100 measurements (7.00%)
     1 (1.00%) high mild
     6 (6.00%) high severe
   
   cast int32 to int64 512 time:   [15.308 us 15.379 us 15.458 us]
                           change: [+0.1736% +0.7831% +1.4380%] (p = 0.01 < 0.05)
                           Change within noise threshold.
   Found 4 outliers among 100 measurements (4.00%)
     1 (1.00%) high mild
     3 (3.00%) high severe
   
   cast date64 to date32 512
                           time:   [17.420 us 17.478 us 17.541 us]
                           change: [-1.5126% -0.4082% +0.6665%] (p = 0.45 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 4 outliers among 100 measurements (4.00%)
     4 (4.00%) high severe
   
   cast date32 to date64 512
                           time:   [16.889 us 16.949 us 17.010 us]
                           change: [-0.5279% -0.0206% +0.4448%] (p = 0.93 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   
   cast time32s to time32ms 512
                           time:   [1.7619 us 1.7692 us 1.7788 us]
                           change: [-0.4364% +0.2991% +0.9890%] (p = 0.42 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
     1 (1.00%) high mild
   
   cast time32s to time64us 512
                           time:   [17.301 us 17.381 us 17.460 us]
                           change: [+0.2890% +0.7191% +1.1969%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                           Change within noise threshold.
   
   cast time64ns to time32s 512
                           time:   [19.485 us 19.630 us 19.804 us]
                           change: [+0.2327% +1.1916% +2.2537%] (p = 0.02 < 0.05)
                           Change within noise threshold.
   Found 8 outliers among 100 measurements (8.00%)
     2 (2.00%) high mild
     6 (6.00%) high severe
   
   cast timestamp_ns to timestamp_s 512
                           time:   [30.630 us 30.801 us 31.016 us]
                           change: [-0.6245% +0.3068% +1.0449%] (p = 0.52 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
     3 (3.00%) high mild
   
   cast timestamp_ms to timestamp_ns 512
                           time:   [2.5006 us 2.5415 us 2.5934 us]
                           change: [-0.6575% +1.0923% +2.6821%] (p = 0.21 > 0.05)
                           No change in performance detected.
   Found 5 outliers among 100 measurements (5.00%)
     1 (1.00%) high mild
     4 (4.00%) high severe
   
   cast timestamp_ms to i64 512
                           time:   [935.31 ns 941.98 ns 950.30 ns]
                           change: [+4.9231% +5.8370% +6.8569%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                           Performance has regressed.
   Found 4 outliers among 100 measurements (4.00%)
     4 (4.00%) high severe
   ```

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description: [ARROW-3882] is too far in the review process to add temporal casts.
fields.summary: [Rust] Support casting temporal arrays in cast kernels

comments.body: I'll submit a PR for this after ARROW-4865 so I don't create merge conflicts. So this should still be possible for 0.13 release
